item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Active Transactions
item_prototype.description: Number of active transactions for the database.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Data File Size
item_prototype.description: Cumulative size (in kilobytes) of all the data files in the database including any automatic growth. Monitoring this counter is useful, for example, for determining the correct size of tempdb.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Log Bytes Flushed/sec
item_prototype.description: Total number of log bytes flushed per second. Useful for determining trends and utilization of the transaction log.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Log File Size
item_prototype.description: Cumulative size (in kilobytes) of all the transaction log files in the database.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Log File Used Size
item_prototype.description: The cumulative used size of all the log files in the database.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Log Flushes/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of log flushes per second.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Log Flush Waits/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of commits per second waiting for the log flush.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Log Flush Wait Time
item_prototype.description: Total wait time (in milliseconds) to flush the log. On an AlwaysOn secondary database, this value indicates the wait time for log records to be hardened to disk.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Log Growths
item_prototype.description: Total number of times the transaction log for the database has been expanded.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Log Shrinks
item_prototype.description: Total number of times the transaction log for the database has been shrunk.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Log Truncations
item_prototype.description: The number of times the transaction log has been shrunk.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Percent Log Used
item_prototype.description: Percentage of space in the log that is in use.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Transactions per second
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}, DB {#DBNAME}: Database Status
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Access Methods\Forwarded Records/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of records per second fetched through forwarded record pointers.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Access Methods\Full Scans/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of unrestricted full scans per second. These can be either base-table or full-index scans.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Access Methods\Index Searches/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of index searches per second. These are used to start a range scan, reposition a range scan, revalidate a scan point, fetch a single index record, and search down the index to locate where to insert a new row.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Access Methods\Page Splits/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Access Methods\Work files created/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of work files created per second. For example, work files could be used to store temporary results for hash joins and hash aggregates.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Access Methods\Work tables created/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of work tables created per second. For example, work tables could be used to store temporary results for query spool, lob variables, XML variables, and cursors.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Bytes Received from Replica/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Bytes Sent to Replica/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Bytes Sent to Transport/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Flow Control/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Flow Control Time (ms/sec)
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Receives from Replica/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Resent Messages/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Sends to Replica/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Sends to Transport/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Buffer Manager\Buffer cache hit ratio
item_prototype.description: Indicates the percentage of pages found in the buffer cache without having to read from disk. The ratio is the total number of cache hits divided by the total number of cache lookups over the last few thousand page accesses. After a long period of time, the ratio moves very little. Because reading from the cache is much less expensive than reading from disk, you want this ratio to be high. Generally, you can increase the buffer cache hit ratio by increasing the amount of memory available to SQL Server or by using the buffer pool extension feature.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Buffer Manager\Checkpoint pages/sec
item_prototype.description: Indicates the number of pages flushed to disk per second by a checkpoint or other operation that require all dirty pages to be flushed.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Buffer Manager\Database pages
item_prototype.description: Indicates the number of pages in the buffer pool with database content.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Buffer Manager\Free list stalls/sec
item_prototype.description: Indicates the number of requests per second that had to wait for a free page.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Buffer Manager\Lazy writes/sec
item_prototype.description: Indicates the number of buffers written per second by the buffer manager's lazy writer. The lazy writer is a system process that flushes out batches of dirty, aged buffers (buffers that contain changes that must be written back to disk before the buffer can be reused for a different page) and makes them available to user processes. The lazy writer eliminates the need to perform frequent checkpoints in order to create available buffers.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Buffer Manager\Page life expectancy
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Buffer Manager\Page lookups/sec
item_prototype.description: Indicates the number of requests per second to find a page in the buffer pool.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Buffer Manager\Page reads/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Buffer Manager\Page writes/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Buffer Manager\Read-ahead pages/sec
item_prototype.description: Indicates the number of pages read per second in anticipation of use.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Buffer Manager\Target pages
item_prototype.description: The optimum number of pages in the buffer pool.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Database Flow Control Delay
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Database Flow Controls/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: File Bytes Received/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Group Commits/Sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Group Commit Time
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Log Bytes Compressed/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Log Bytes Decompressed/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Log Bytes Received/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Log Compression Cache hits/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Log Compression Cache misses/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Log Compressions/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Log Decompressions/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Log remaining for undo
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Log Send Queue
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Mirrored Write Transactions/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Recovery Queue
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Redo blocked/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Redo Bytes Remaining
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Redone Bytes/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Redones/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Total Log requiring undo
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Transaction Delay
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Databases(_Total)\Data File Size
item_prototype.description: Total size (in kilobytes) of all the data files.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Databases(_Total)\Log File Size
item_prototype.description: Total size (in kilobytes) of all the transaction log files.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Databases(_Total)\Log File Used Size
item_prototype.description: The cumulative used size of all the log files in the database.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Databases(_Total)\Percent Log Used
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Databases(_Total)\Transactions/sec
item_prototype.description: Total number of transactions started for all databases per second.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:General Statistics\Logins/sec
item_prototype.description: Total number of logins started per second. This does not include pooled connections.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:General Statistics\Logouts/sec
item_prototype.description: Total number of logout operations started per second.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:General Statistics\Number of Blocked Processes
item_prototype.description: Number of currently blocked processes.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:General Statistics\User Connections
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Jobs(_Total)\Number of Failed Jobs
item_prototype.description: The number of jobs with a last run status of Failed.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Latches\Average Latch Wait Time
item_prototype.description: Average latch wait time (in milliseconds) for latch requests that had to wait.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Latches\Latch Waits/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of latch requests that could not be granted immediately.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Latches\Total Latch Wait Time
item_prototype.description: Total latch wait time (in milliseconds) for latch requests in the last second.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Locks(_Total)\Average Wait Time
item_prototype.description: Total wait time (in milliseconds) for locks in the last second.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Locks(_Total)\Lock Requests/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of new locks and lock conversions per second requested from the lock manager.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Locks(_Total)\Lock Timeouts/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Locks(_Total)\Lock Waits/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of lock requests per second that required the caller to wait.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Locks(_Total)\Lock Wait Time
item_prototype.description: Average amount of wait time (in milliseconds) for each lock request that resulted in a wait.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Locks(_Total)\Number of Deadlocks/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Memory Manager\Granted Workspace Memory
item_prototype.description: Specifies the total amount of memory currently granted to executing processes, such as hash, sort, bulk copy, and index creation operations.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Memory Manager\Maximum Workspace Memory
item_prototype.description: Indicates the maximum amount of memory available for executing processes, such as hash, sort, bulk copy, and index creation operations.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Memory Manager\Memory Grants Outstanding
item_prototype.description: Specifies the total number of processes that have successfully acquired a workspace memory grant.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Memory Manager\Memory Grants Pending
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Memory Manager\Target Server Memory (KB)
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Memory Manager\Total Server Memory (KB)
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Cache\Cache Hit Ratio
item_prototype.description: Ratio between cache hits and lookups.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Cache\Cache Object Counts
item_prototype.description: Number of cache objects in the cache.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Cache\Cache Objects in use
item_prototype.description: Number of cache objects in use.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Cache\Cache Pages
item_prototype.description: Number of 8-kilobyte (KB) pages used by cache objects.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Errors\DB Offline Errors/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of errors/sec.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Errors\Info Errors/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of errors/sec.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Errors\Kill Connection Errors/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Errors\User Errors/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of errors/sec.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}: Errors\Total/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of errors/sec.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:SQL Statistics\Auto-Param Attempts/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of auto-parameterization attempts per second. Total should be the sum of the failed, safe, and unsafe auto-parameterizations. Auto-parameterization occurs when an instance of SQL Server tries to parameterize a Transact-SQL request by replacing some literals with parameters so that reuse of the resulting cached execution plan across multiple similar-looking requests is possible. Note that auto-parameterizations are also known as simple parameterizations in newer versions of SQL Server. This counter does not include forced parameterizations.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:SQL Statistics\Batch Requests/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:SQL Statistics\Failed Auto-Params/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of failed auto-parameterization attempts per second. This should be small. Note that auto-parameterizations are also known as simple parameterizations in later versions of SQL Server.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:SQL Statistics\Safe Auto-Params/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of safe auto-parameterization attempts per second. Safe refers to a determination that a cached execution plan can be shared between different similar-looking Transact-SQL statements. SQL Server makes many auto-parameterization attempts some of which turn out to be safe and others fail. Note that auto-parameterizations are also known as simple parameterizations in later versions of SQL Server. This does not include forced parameterizations.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:SQL Statistics\SQL Compilations/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:SQL Statistics\SQL Re-Compilations/sec
SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:SQL Statistics\Unsafe Auto-Params/sec
item_prototype.description: Number of unsafe auto-parameterization attempts per second. For example, the query has some characteristics that prevent the cached plan from being shared. These are designated as unsafe. This does not count the number of forced parameterizations.

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Page IO latch waits/Waits in progress
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\{#INST}:Wait Statistics(Waits in progress)\Page IO latch waits"]

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Memory grant queue waits/Waits started per second
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\{#INST}:Wait Statistics(Waits started per second)\Memory grant queue waits"]

item_prototype.name: SQL Server, Instance {#INST}:Network IO waits/Waits started per second
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\{#INST}:Wait Statistics(Waits started per second)\Network IO waits"]
